review_title: One of the best places I've ever worked
pros: WfWI is a really collaborative and supportive team. Passion for the work runs through all employees and there is a real effort to make systemic policies and processes which increase staff benefits. New Co-MDs are really approachable and strong leaders, who lead by example.
cons: In the last year, the organisation has gone through a restructure which has had a huge impact on the organisation. That said, the new WfWI is better than ever and achieving incredible results.

pros: Good work culture which is flexible
Great cause for women in war zones

review_title: UK office rife with bullying and toxicity.
pros: Solidarity among junior colleagues is a lifeline. The mission is genuinely inspiring, and you meet an incredible collective of feminists.
cons:
My time at WfWI - UK was incredibly difficult. The outgoing CEO and Managing Director perpetuated a culture of toxicity, with several colleagues having to leave due to the treatment they experienced. Within the communications team, bullying and micro-management was rife, with relatively unskilled individuals being constantly promoted. Workload was also unbearably high, with little slack. Many team members lived in fear of the communications teams due to senior figures within it bullying, being disrespectful and sometimes even name-calling. 

Staff turnover is very high, they cycle through staff and then mock them when they 'can't handle how fast paced' the charity was. The charity is not fast paced, it is in fact one that pushes people to the limit and goes against it's feminist values in the way it treats and pays its majority-female staff. I was once told I was too positive, and needed to adopt more manly traits to succeed.

No qualified HR individual means that recurring cases of staff being bullied or burnt out by departments has gone unresolved. As a result, it wasn't uncommon to see multiple staff in the office in tears at any given time.

Other reviews have mentioned nepotism, and I must agree. People who had been with the charity a long time were often promoted to roles they had no experience in, simply because they were in with senior management and meshed well with the false feminism and toxic positivity. Inevitably, this has meant that outside applicants from more diverse backgrounds have been unsuccessful with little justifiable reason.

pros: A supportive and kind team full of passion and ambition. Very mission focused.
cons: Lack of clarity around progression. Workload can be high at times
